description: Borrowed from Middle French révoquer, from Latin revocare, from re- + voco, vocare. Doublet of revocate.

entries.meaning: The act of revoking in a game of cards.
examples: Employ two revokes, two trumpings of your partner's best card and two ignorings of a call — all in the same hand!

entries.meaning: A renege; a violation of important rules regarding the play of tricks in trick-taking card games serious enough to render the round invalid.
A violation ranked in seriousness somewhat below overt cheating, with the status of a more minor offense only because, when it happens, it is usually accidental.

verbs.description: revoke (third-person singular simple present revokes, present participle revoking, simple past and past participle revoked) # (intransitive) To fail to follow suit in a game of cards when holding a card in that suit.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cancel or invalidate by withdrawing or reversing.
examples: Your driver's license will be revoked.
I hereby revoke all former wills.
